definition:
Let $H$ and $K$ be subgroups of a group $G$. An *$(H,K)$-double coset*
is a set of the form $HxK$ for some $x\in G$. Here $HxK$ is defined in
the obvious way as $$HxK = \{ hxk \mid h\in H \hbox{ and } k\in K \}.$$

Note that the $(H,\{1\})$-double cosets are just the right cosets of
$H$, and the $(\{1\},K)$-double cosets are just the left cosets of $K$.
In general, every $(H,K)$-double coset is a union of right cosets of
$H$, and also a union of left cosets of $K$.

The set of all $(H,K)$-double cosets is denoted $H\backslash G/K$. It is
straightforward to show that $H\backslash G/K$ is a of $G$, that is,
every element of $G$ lies in exactly one $(H,K)$-double coset.

In contrast to the situation with ordinary , the $(H,K)$-double cosets
need not all be of the same cardinality. For example, if $G$ is the
$S_3$, and $H=\genby{(1,2)}$ and $K=\genby{(1,3)}$, then the two
$(H,K)$-double cosets are $\{e,(1,2),(1,3),(1,3,2)\}$ and
$\{(2,3),(1,2,3)\}$.
